ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very few.
Topics on the myth of anthropocene causality. How humans have (and have not) impacted the world.

In this course, we learned about the historical events that all contribute to the problem of the Anthropocene. The historical events/concepts covered date back thousands of years ago to today, and include hunting/gathering, surplus, early cities and states, empires, societal collapse, the bronze age, mayan collapse, capitalism, feudalism, the forty thieves, the great acceleration, and more. We tracked all of this concepts through presentations and readings and were able to dig deeper into one of them in our own presentations/papers.
I learned about human impacts on the earth across history.

Nothing was learned in this course the entire semester and then he randomly gave us a final exam and a final paper. He couldn't just choose one. He also made us do presentations and we never received feedback for that. This course was a total joke the entire semester until the end when the professor decided that it was time to be serious. He suddenly got very stern and rude even snapping at students when they asked about the grading structure for the class where there was entirely no clarity. This man literally just repeated all of the same things and never even bothered to define The Anthropocene. He then proceeded to grade students very harshly on final assignments when he did not even teach us what he wanted us to include in the final exam and the final paper. I have not seen anyone who does not teach at all expect such a high return from students that have not learned anything.
Knowledge into the human impact on earth from an archaeological, socio-cultural lens

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The workload is low
Weaknesses: Pretty much everything. This course was incredibly disorganized and I felt like every single thing we did was randomly thought of on the spot by Professor Weiss. He did not provide any clarity on assignments or grading and I learned almost nothing the entire semester.

Strengths: Very nice class to take if the rest of your schedule is super demanding since this class does not demand much outside of a few readings each week. Weaknesses: Professor gave absolutely no feedback and the format of the course schedule was constantly changing, so it was very hard to get a good understanding of where you are in the class.

The strengths of this course was the breadth of information covered and the ability to own one of the concepts taught throughout the semester. Each student effectively picked a topic that they wanted to become the expert on... and then they would present that topic to the class via powerpoint presentation on the day that it was assigned. They then had a chance to dig deeper into that topic in the final term paper. The course could be improved by facilitating more of a conversation -- oftentimes the seminar felt as though it were a lecture and there was limited ability to participate or ask questions outside of being the presenter of that days topic.
Good overview of issues in defining the Anthropocene, but perhaps too broad to really dive into particular topics. Could be refined in content!
The professor was very passionate, and the readings and content were very interesting. However, I think the lectures could stand to be more structured.

Strengths: There were none
Weaknesses: Professor Weiss was clearly mentally unstable. This octogenarian has lost his marbles. The first half of the semester Professor Weiss spent too much time talking about Gobekli Tepe and cave stalagmites. The second half was composed of student presentations that dragged on for over 20 minutes. It appeared as though this man simply did not want to teach but wanted to collect a check for his research from Yale University. He is the professor at an ivy league university that students are warned about. However, whenever a student would ask for a meeting with Professor Weiss, he never seemed to be busy. However, he was apparently too busy during actual class time to teach his students...

While the material was interesting, this seminar was a complete disaster. Our class was very disorganized, with readings often missing from the syllabus, the expectations constantly changing, and no clear direction to the lectures. Prof. Weiss was clearly very passionate about the content, but would spend most of the class going on confusing tangents without space for students to interject or ask questions. I personally didn't feel able to participate in the class, as the only way seemed to be interrupting the professor or volunteering a right answer to a confusing questionit often felt like there was a right answer (his opinion) to completely subjective issues. Our professor also struggled with technology, making class difficult at times. The strength of this class was the student presentations, from which I learned a lot; this class would likely be so much better if it was a true seminar, rather than a long, confusing lecture!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having the lectures be recorded for future reference would be helpful.

The in class presentations were great for the online learning format as it not only gave the students some autonomy over some of the concepts, but it also provided critical study guide information that helped make the studying for the final exam way more efficient. I think that a class with more of a discussion focus could greatly improve engagement and excitement about the material, as some times it was difficult to know when you could ask questions/how the material all linked together.
The course was well-adapted to the pandemic.

No Successes; All Failures
He canceled our midterm which was on a break day and then refused to offer any feedback on what our grade was in the class. He in fact told us it was wrong to ask about our grades. Imagine that! We went through the entire semester not knowing anything about our grade because this man was clearly here for a good time and not a long time. The professor made up everything on the spot, including the questions for the exam, the topics for presentations, and term papers. I have never seen anyone use a syllabus that they made as a light suggestion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No I would absolutely not recommend this class to anyone else. Professor Weiss is incredibly disorganized and will not provide any sort of structure to the course. Every day will be a randomized assortment of topics and you will receive no feedback in terms of grading until you receive your final grade. I have never been more confused by a course and truly regret taking it.
Yes! It was an interesting course with nice conversations, and not a lot of workload.

I would certainly suggest this course to someone who was interested in learning more about the historical events and concepts that helped spark and contribute to the Anthropocene. This course is geared toward someone who is interested in history, as it is a historical understanding of the catalysts and implications of them for the Anthropocene problem.
Yes, it was a fun an interesting class that provided an important perspective on how humans impact the earth.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they want to have a grade that is similar to a randomized Sim outfit. At first, this course was fun because Professor Weiss is a character that you might meet in a cartoon. He was very entertaining. But then as we neared the end of the semester, the facade fell and what was left was a man who was past his prime who was deciding the fate of your GPA. I thought this was a gut, and I suppose there was not much work to actually do. But your grade is literally a toss-up, so I would not recommend it unless you Credit/D. But even then, he has given a student a D, so I don't even think that is safe!
Yes!! Wonderful class and a great professor!

No. While this is indeed a very low workload course, it was not worth itclass was consistently disorganized and confusing and seemed to be a long monologue of our professor's opinions on various issues. I was initially very excited to take the course and tried my best to engage with the material, but I came out of most classes confused and frustrated. Save yourself the stress!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
